revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{good article}} [[File:Sepp Blatter (2009).jpg|thumb|right|[[Sepp Blatter]], when president of FIFA, football's world governing body, strongly opposed the "game 39" proposal.]] '''"Game 39"''' or the '''international round''' was a proposed extra round of matches in the [[Premier League]] to be played at neutral venues outside England. The top [[association football|football]] league in England, the Premier League is currently played on a [[double round robin]] basis, where each team plays the other 19 [[home and away]], giving a total of 38 games. The international round was proposed at a meeting of the 20 Premier League clubs on 7 February 2008, with a view to being introduced for the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]], when a new television [[Premier League#Media coverage|broadcasting rights contract]] would be in place. The proposed start date was later put back to [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14]]. The proposal was reportedly endorsed by the chairmen of a number of Premier League clubs.
Game 39 resulted in opposition from several club managers. The proposal also met with strong condemnation from supporters' organisations, who saw it as solely motivated by money to the detriment of fans. [[Sepp Blatter]], president of the sport's global governing body at that time, expressed a negative opinion of the proposal and stated that it could affect [[English 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid to host the 2018 World Cup]], and the football authorities in a number of the areas suggested as possible venues for the matches were also opposed. In May 2010, the Premier League said that it was no longer actively considering game 39,<ref>{{cite news|title=Premier League rules out revival of 39th-game proposal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/09/premier-league-39th-round|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=31 January 2013|date=9 May 2010}}</ref> but in October 2014 it was said to be re-considering the idea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gibson|first1=Owen|title=Premier League to look again at playing competitive matches abroad|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/07/premier-league-38th-game-overseas-fixtures|accessdate=25 October 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=7 October 2014}}</ref>
==Proposal== The [[Premier League]], the top-level [[association football|football]] league in England, contains 20 member clubs, with each playing the others once at home and once away for a total of 38 games per season.<ref name="tel0208"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/08/sfnfro108.xml |title=Premier League to embark on world tour |first=David |last=Bond |date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref> The proposal envisaged each team playing one further match, a total of ten extra matches, over one weekend in January.<ref name="tel0208"/> Two matches would be played in each of five cities, one each on Saturday and Sunday.<ref name="tel0208"/> Cities would bid for the right to stage matches, but would not be able to specify which teams would be involved.<ref name="tel0208"/> The matches would be held at staggered start times, with venues in different [[timezone]]s, making it possible in theory to watch live television coverage of all ten.<ref name="tel0208"/> There are conflicting reports about whether the draw for the extra fixtures would be [[seed (sports)|seeded]] or not.<ref name="winter12"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/12/sfnfro112.xml |title=Richard Scudamore signals his intent for future |first=Henry |last=Winter |date=12 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref>
The week prior to the international round would be free of matches, to allow for travel and [[acclimatisation]].<ref name="tel0208"/> The week after the international round would see each team face one of the teams which had played at the same foreign venue, to avoid any disadvantage for teams with a longer round-trip.<ref name="winter12"/> Possible venues suggested for international-round matches were Australia, [[East Asia]], [[Southeast Asia]], the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Gulf States]], and [[North America]].<ref name="tel0208"/> All are wealthy regions where interest in English football is strong relative to the level of the domestic game. Venues would have warm, predictable weather, unlike England in January.<ref name="tel0208"/>
Premier League chief executive [[Richard Scudamore]] initially said there would not be more than one international round per season, stating "I stress that on my watch, there will be no 40th game. The value [of a 39th game] is in its uniqueness, in that festival weekend, so there's no point in diluting it".<ref name="winter"/> Subsequently, he suggested the initial plan would last six to ten years and might be altered.<ref name="winter11"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/11/sfnwin111.xml |title=Richard Scudamore reneges on foreign fixtures |first=Henry |last=Winter |date=11 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref>
==Development== Foreshadowing the plan were the [[Premier League Asia Trophy]], started in 2003, and the [[NFL International Series]] [[American football]] game played at [[Wembley Stadium]] in [[London]] in 2007.<ref name="tel0208"/> [[Rod Eddington]] pitched the idea of an international round to the Premier League in autumn 2007.<ref name="mailedd"> {{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=514169&in_page_id=1779 |title=Revealed: The man behind Gam£ 39 (... and he's not even keen on it anymore) |date=14 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[Daily Mail]] }} </ref><ref name="murdochman"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/14/sfnfro214.xml |title=Murdoch man behind League's global plan |first=David |last=Bond |date=14 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref> Eddington was chairman of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]n Major Events Company and a friend of [[Rupert Murdoch]], owner of [[Sky Sports]] and other networks with broadcasting rights to the Premier League.<ref name="murdochman"/> He suggested his home city of [[Melbourne]] as an inaugural host city.<ref name="mailedd"/> A presentation to the Premier League's audit-and-remuneration committee was made two weeks before the public announcement.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/02/22/time_for_scuby_to_admit_his_ow.html |title=Time for Scuby to admit his own shortcomings |first=Matt |last=Scott |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-22 |work=[[The Guardian]] }} </ref> An initial [[business plan]] predicted extra earnings from the international round of between £40 million and £80 million per year.<ref name="tel0208"/>
The Premier League put in place a working party to negotiate with the various concerned parties.<ref name="winter12"/> It initially stated that, to proceed with the plan, it needed the support only of [[the Football Association]] (FA) and the football governing bodies of the countries of the host cities.<ref name="winter11"/> It attempted to secure the support of the FA for the proposal by promising to rearrange club fixtures for better convenience to players called up to the [[England national football team|England team]].<ref name="winter"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/08/sfnfro108.xml |title=Premier League must not alienate ordinary fans |first=Henry |last=Winter |date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref> Scudamore planned to meet officials from the sport's global governing body, the [[FIFA|International Federation of Association Football]] (FIFA), before its executive committee meeting in [[Zurich]] on 14 March 2008.<ref name="winter11"/> On 27 February, after several weeks of mostly negative reaction, Scudamore agreed with [[Jérôme Valcke]], general secretary of FIFA, that the meeting would be postponed indefinitely.<ref name="guar27feb"> {{cite news |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=27 February 2008 |title=Scudamore forced to climb down over Game 39 |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,,2260181,00.html |first=Paul |last=Kelso |accessdate=2008-02-28}} </ref> The Premier League presented this as an opportunity to rethink its proposals, and said that it would not proceed without FIFA approval.<ref name="guar27feb"/>
In May 2008, Scudamore told [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] that the proposal was "not over", but that the League would "come up with something that ticks more boxes" by January 2009.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=533974&&cc=3888 |title=Scudamore - 39th game idea 'not over' |work=[[ESPNsoccernet]] |date=11 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-06-03}} </ref> In August 2008, Scudamore said that the League had "a whole host of ideas, some more radical than others, but none quite as radical as the original concept".<ref> {{cite news|title= Game 39 on hold |last=Bascombe |first=Chris |date=17 August 2008 |work=[[News of the World]] }}</ref> In October 2008, he said Game 39 was still a possibility,<ref name="sbp" /> although the timing of TV contracts meant it would be in the 2013–14 season at the earliest.<ref name="pp2013"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/3168613/Five-year-wait-for-Game-39-of-Premier-League-Football.html |title=Five-year wait for Game 39; Premier League run out of time to negotiate TV deal for international round |last=Kelso |first=Paul |date=10 October 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref> An agreement in December 2008 between the Premier League and the [[Asian Football Confederation]] (AFC) was linked to Game 39 by the media.<ref> {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/7779124.stm |title=Premier League agrees Asia link |date=12 December 2008|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref>
==Reactions==
===In England=== [[Image:David Gold.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[David Gold (businessman)|David Gold]], then chairman of [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], endorsed the idea.]] Richard Scudamore defended the plan as consolidating the Premier League's global reputation, saying "if we didn't do it, another sport will come and do it to us".<ref name="tel0208"/> Scudamore said that the chairmen of all 20 Premier League clubs supported the proposal, and disputed claims by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' that [[Randy Lerner]] of [[Aston Villa]] and [[Dave Whelan]] of [[Wigan Athletic]] were opposed.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=514169&in_page_id=1779 |title=Premier League chairmen are fully behind Gam£ 39, insists under-fire Scudamore |date=13 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[Daily Mail]] }} </ref> [[David Gold (businessman)|David Gold]], chairman of [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], endorsed the plan in part because the larger clubs have in any case already been exploiting foreign markets, with pre-season and even mid-season tours; Game 39 would distribute its revenue among all the clubs.<ref name="fans"/> On 15 February, [[Liverpool F.C.]] chief executive [[Rick Parry]] stated that the proposal had "never been on Liverpool's club agenda" and acknowledged the concern of the club's fans and manager.<ref> {{cite web |title=Parry: Game 39 not 'On Liverpool's agenda' |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=508155 |work=[[ESPNsoccernet]] |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 }} </ref> Paul Hayward, writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', said that the proposal would destroy the balance of the home-and-away round-robin league.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/may/20/seven-deadly-sins-football-gluttony-premier-league-game-39 |title=Foul play: The seven deadly sins of football: Day five: Gluttony: The Premier League and Game 39: England, 2008 |last=Hayward |first=Paul |date=20 May 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} </ref> The [[Football Supporters' Federation]] (FSF) condemned the proposal as being motivated by money, and dubbed it '''Gam£39'''.<ref name="fans"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/08/sfnfro108.xml |title=Premier League money-driven, say angry fans |first=Jeremy |last=Wilson |date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref> It launched a [[petition]], with the support of the ''Daily Mail'', to oppose the "outrageous [[desecration]] of the [[National sport|national game]]". In March 2008, the campaign was ended as the FSF declared the proposal "effectively dead".<ref name="fsf"> {{cite web |url=http://www.fsf.org.uk/campaigns/news110endofgame39.php |title=End of Game 39 |publisher=[[Football Supporters' Federation]] |accessdate=2008-06-03 }} </ref> Many die-hard fans who pride themselves on travelling to all their teams' away matches would have been unable to travel abroad for "Game 39".<ref name="winter"/> On the other hand, exotic foreign venues would potentially be more appealing destinations for fans than a mundane English city.<ref name="winter12"/> [[Manager (football)|Manager]]s of Premier League clubs reported to be opposed to or sceptical of the plans included [[Steve Bruce]],<ref name="fans"/> [[Roy Hodgson]],<ref name="fans"/> [[Gareth Southgate]],<ref name="fans"/> and [[Rafael Benítez]].<ref name="bbcfa"/> [[Alex Ferguson]] criticised the club owners for lack of consultation with managers.<ref name="bbcplat"/> [[Arsène Wenger]],<ref name="bbcfa"/><ref name="bbcplat"/><ref name="blatter"/> [[Roy Keane]],<ref name="bbcplat"/> [[Kevin Keegan]],<ref name="bbcplat"/> and [[Avram Grant]]<ref name="blatter"/> supported the proposal. 'Game 39' was also defended as a move to head off plans for a World League involving only elite clubs such as those formerly in the [[G-14]] group.<ref name="winter12"/>
[[Andy Burnham]], the [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport]], cautioned that football should "not forget its roots".<ref name="fans"/> [[Gordon Taylor (footballer)|Gordon Taylor]] of the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] expressed concern about increased pressure on players.<ref name="bbcplat"/> The FA on 15 February expressed "serious reservations" that the proposal might damage [[England 2018 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid to host the 2018 World Cup]].<ref name="bbcfa"> {{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7246314.stm |title=FA concerned over top-flight plan |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |publisher=[[BBC]] }} </ref><ref> {{cite news |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2257305,00.html |work=[[The Guardian]] |title=Nervous FA rules Game 39 a step too far: Potentially fatal blow to Premier League's plan: Barwick not willing to risk damage to World Cup bid |first=Paul |last=Kelso |date=16 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 }} </ref> An FA board meeting on 21 February concluded that the plan was "unsustainable in its current format".<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/21/ufnprem121.xml |title=FA oppose Premier League's 39th step |first=Patrick |last=Nathanson |author2=agencies |date=21 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-22 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref>
===Elsewhere=== The proposal was condemned by [[Sepp Blatter]], president of [[FIFA]], who said it brought the game into disrepute and would adversely affect [[English 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid for the 2018 World Cup]].<ref name="blatter"> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/15/sfnfro415.xml |title=Wenger hits out at Blatter over 'Game 39'|date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }}</ref> He also said "Football cannot be like the [[Harlem Globetrotters]] or a [[circus]]".<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/15/sfnfro415.xml&page=2 |title=Wenger hits out at Blatter over 'Game 39'(page 2) |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }}</ref> [[Michel Platini]] of the sport's European governing body, [[UEFA]], called it a "nonsense idea".<ref name="bbcplat"> {{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7234304.stm |title=Platini scorns global games plan |date=9 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |publisher=[[BBC]] }}</ref> Strong reservations were expressed by [[Korea Football Association|the Korean FA]], and [[Japan Football Association|the Japanese FA]] opposed the plan.<ref name="asia"> {{cite news |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2255917,00.html?gusrc=rss&feed=5 |work=[[The Guardian]] |title=Asian Football Confederation rejects global proposals: 'It is not a good idea to organise domestic leagues in territories other than their own' |first=John |last=Ashdown |author2=news agencies |date=12 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 }} </ref> Middle-eastern FAs were reportedly more positive.<ref name="asia"/> In February 2008 AFC president [[Mohammed Bin Hammam]] said he would "vote strongly against" the proposal;<ref name="murdochman"/> in June he was prepared to reconsider if the plan had FA support;<ref> {{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/2303732/Premier-League-Game-39-back-on-agenda-after-head-of-Asian-footballs-U-turn.html|title=Game 39 back on agenda after head of Asian football's U-turn|date=21 Jun 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref> in October he said he would welcome it if the League shared revenue with the AFC.<ref name="sbp"> {{cite news|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2008/10/12/story36613.asp|title=Credit crunch helps put 'Game 39' back on the agenda|last=Maher |first=Linda |date=12 October 2008|work=Sunday Business Post |accessdate=2009-10-14}} </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/oct/10/footballpolitics|title=Yes from Asia puts Game 39 back on menu|last=Conn |first=David |date=12 October 2008 |work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref> The [[Hong Kong Football Association|Hong Kong FA]] said it was "very interested" in hosting games.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2008/02/15/sfnfro415.xml&page=3 |title=Wenger hits out at Blatter over 'Game 39' (page 3) |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] }} </ref> [[Football Federation Australia]] said it would oppose it if it impacted its own [[A-League]].<ref name="murdochman"/> [[Ivan Gazidis]], deputy commissioner of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) in the United States, said that MLS would welcome the plan if it had FIFA approval.<ref> {{cite news |title=MLS keen to be involved: Deputy commissioner awaits Fifa verification |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_3129562,00.html |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=10 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 }} </ref> [[Sunil Gulati]], the president of the [[United States Soccer Federation|US Soccer Federation]], said the USSF would be guided by FIFA about approving any matches.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/internationals/america-deals-blow-to-scudamores-global-plan-781104.html |title=America deals blow to Scudamore's global plan |first=Nick |last=Harris |date=12 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work=[[The Independent]] }} </ref>
==Aftermath== Since 2013, Relevent Sports has run the [[International Champions Cup]], a series of summer matches between teams from the Premier League and other top European sides, held in overseas markets including Asia and North America. In August 2018 Relevent announced a partnership with [[La Liga]] under which a regular-season fixture would be staged in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |author=Associated Press |title=La Liga set to stage match in US as battle to match Premier League grows |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/aug/16/la-liga-stage-match-us |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=16 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The proposal was compared to Game 39 in ''[[The Guardian]]'' by Ed Aarons, who speculated both that opposition from Spanish fans might stop Relevent's plan, and that Relevent might seek a similar arrangement with the Premier League.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Aarons |first1=Ed |title=Could La Liga’s US venture spark a Premier export? {{!}} Ed Aarons |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/aug/16/la-liga-us-deal-39th-game-premier-league |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=16 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

(1949–66) | general_contractor = J. C. Watts Construction Company | tenants = [[Oregon State Beavers]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) [[OSAA]] Class 5A State Basketball Championships (1999-2006 and 2007–2014) partial schedule | seating_capacity = 9,604 (2011–present){{cite web |title=Oregon State (12–7, 2–5) vs. USC 5–14, 0–6)|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/orst/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/2011-12/release/release_20120120aaa.pdf|publisher=Oregon State Athletics|date=January 20, 2012|accessdate=November 13, 2013}}
10,400 (1984–2011)
10,000 (1949–1984) }} '''Gill Coliseum''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] located on the campus of [[Oregon State University]] (OSU) in [[Corvallis, Oregon]]. Opened {{Years or months ago|1949}} in 1949, the arena has a [[seating capacity]] of 9,604 and is home to the [[Oregon State Beavers]]' basketball, [[Collegiate wrestling|wrestling]], volleyball, and gymnastics teams. It is named after basketball coach [[Slats Gill|Amory T. "Slats" Gill]], who compiled a 599–392 ({{winning percentage|599|392}}) record in 36 seasons—from 1928 to 1964. The court is named after another OSU coach, [[Ralph Miller]], who led the men's basketball program from 1971 to 1989. The building also houses a [[weight room]], equipment center, [[locker room]]s, and offices for the Oregon State University athletic department and its teams. Inside, on the south wall of Gill Coliseum is a painted [[mural]] of many former Oregon State men's basketball players including [[Gary Payton]], [[Brent Barry]], [[AC Green]], [[Lester Conner]], and [[Steve Johnson (basketball)|Steve Johnson]]. ==History== Prior to the construction of Gill Coliseum, intercollegiate basketball games were hosted in the [[Oregon Agricultural College Gymnasium]],{{cite journal|date=Spring 2010|title=Legendary Hoop Star Red Rocha, Tower of the ‘Thrill Kids,’ Dies|journal=Oregon Stater|publisher=OSU Alumni Association|volume=95|issue=2|page=32|url=http://www.osualum.com/s/359/file_lib/1/28/201004_sports_634055524876424940.pdf}} constructed in 1914.[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4677959/oregon_agricultural_colleges_new_gym/ OAC's New Gym, Scene of Commencement Activities,"] ''Corvallis Gazette-Times,'' vol. 6, no. 28 (June 4, 1914), pg. 1. This building continues to stand as the current [[Langton Hall (Oregon State University)|Langton Hall]]. Gill Coliseum opened in 1949 and housed the '''Horner Museum''' in the basement until the museum's colsure in 1995.{{cite news|last1=Tomlinson|first1=Stuart|title=Presidential tokens stolen from Oregon State University museum returned 50 years later|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2014/08/presidential_tokens_stolen_fro.html|accessdate=27 August 2014|work=The Oregonian|date=August 26, 2014}} The facility has a [[sports medicine]] center, located on the lower level of the coliseum, that provides injury prevention and rehabilitation services. The center includes cardiovascular equipment and improved training facilities. Part of a $7 million renovation of the arena in 2009 included making Gill compliant with the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]].{{cite journal|date=Fall 2009|title=Barrels of paint for Gill; big plans for the area|journal=Oregon Stater|volume=94|issue=3|pages=48|url=http://www.osualum.com/s/359/file_lib/1/25/spring09Stater_WEB_4451_633875952129294886.pdf}} The renovation also included sandblasting the exterior and applying new paint. New windows were installed on the east and west sides of the coliseum. The court has gone numerous remodels as Oregon State has updated their [[sports marketing|branding]]. Prior to the 2013–14 season, the court was updated to reflect the athletic department's re-branding along with some graphics surrounding the lower seating.{{cn|date=May 2018}} Construction of the '''Sports Performance Center''' ('''SPC''') began in early 2007, and work was completed in spring 2008. The building is located between Gill Coliseum and the [[Tommy Prothro]] Football Complex. The SPC houses a practice facility for wrestling and offices for the weight training staff. The {{Convert|20000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} building is the home to over $500,000 in training equipment and a 4-lane {{Convert|60|yd|m|adj=on}} sprint track. The four-story facility includes two full-size regulation courts and basketball offices which opened in June 2013.{{cite news |title=Oregon State Celebrates Opening of Basketball Practice Facility|first=Lindsay|last=Schnell|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/beavers/index.ssf/2013/06/oregon_state_celebrates_openin.html#incart_m-rpt-2|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|location=Portland, OR|date=June 11, 2013|accessdate=June 12, 2013}} ==Gallery== File:Gill Coliseum exterior 1956.jpeg|The exterior of Gill Coliseum in 1956 File:Gill Coliseum entrance.JPG|The facade of Gill Coliseum photographed in May 2008 File:Gill Coliseum interior 1956.jpeg|A basketball game in Gill Coliseum, circa 1956 File:Gill Coliseum.jpg|The basketball court at Gill Coliseum in 2007 ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] * [[Chiles Center]] * [[McArthur Court]] * [[Veterans Memorial Coliseum (Portland, Oregon)]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.osubeavers.com/facilities/?id=4 Gill Coliseum] (Oregon State Athletics official website) {{OSUtemplate}} {{Oregon State Beavers men's basketball navbox}} {{Oregon State Beavers women's basketball navbox}} {{Pacific-12 Conference basketball venue navbox}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Oregon]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College gymnastics venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Oregon]] [[Category:Oregon State Beavers basketball]] [[Category:Oregon State Beavers women's gymnastics venues]] [[Category:Oregon State Beavers volleyball]] [[Category:Oregon State Beavers wrestling]] [[Category:Oregon State University buildings]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Benton County, Oregon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1949]] [[Category:1949 establishments in Oregon]]

(6 February 2003) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = }} '''Hallstabacken''' are [[ski jumping]] hills in [[Sollefteå]], [[Sweden]]. ==History== It was built from 1930-1933 and owned by Sollefteå GIF. It was opened on 25 February 1934. It hosted [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1934]] and one [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] event in 1990 on normal hill. [[Thomas Morgenstern]] holds the hill record. ==World Cup== ===Men=== {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="background:#ffffff; font-size:95%; border:grey solid 1px; border-collapse:collapse;" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" !width="90"| Date !width="69"| Size !width="200"| Winner !width="200"| Second !width="200"| Third |- | 11 Mar 1990 | align=center|K-107 | {{flagicon|TCH}} [[Pavel Ploc]] | {{flagicon|FIN}} [[Ari-Pekka Nikkola]] | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Virginio Lunardi]] |} {{coord|63.1579|N|17.2467|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Sweden]] [[Category:Sport in Sweden]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1934]] [[Category:1934 establishments in Sweden]] {{Skijumping-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Dyson Award|the international design competition|James Dyson Award}} The '''Mussabini Medal''' was a sports award recognising the [[coach (sport)|coaches]] of [[United Kingdom|British]] sports people and teams, named after [[Sam Mussabini]].<ref name=Ind10Dec2000/> Mussabini, who died in 1927, is considered to be the first professional (paid) coach in sport, breaking the occupation's amateur (voluntary) [[Public school (government funded)|public school]] roots. Introduced in 1998, it was awarded annually as part of the UK Coaching Awards organised by sports coach UK (the National Coaching Foundation) until 2007, when the 2008 awards categories onwards were renamed and expanded as part of the launch of the UK Coaching Framework.<ref name=2008Awards>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportscoachuk.org/index.php?PageID=6&sc=28&uid=25 |title=UK Coaching awards 2008 |publisher=sports coach UK |date=2008 |accessdate=2009-10-14 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kWnqM8zM |archivedate=2009-10-14 }}</ref><ref name=About>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportscoachuk.org/index.php?PageID=6&sc=28&uid=70 |title=What are the UK Coaching Awards? |publisher=sports coach UK |date=n.d. |accessdate=2009-10-14 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kWo8v7HX |archivedate=2009-10-14 }}</ref>
The Mussabini Medal celebrated "the contribution of coaches of UK performers who have achieved outstanding success on the world stage."<ref name=UKSport27Sep2001/> Along with the Mussabini Medal, there also existed '''The Dyson Award''', for "individuals who have made a sustained and significant contribution to the development and management of coaching and individual coaches in the UK".<ref name=UKSport27Sep2001/> This award was named after [[Geoff Dyson]], the first chief national athletics coach, who died in 1981.<ref name=Ind10Dec2000/><ref name=EnglandAthletics2008/>
The Mussabini Medal was introduced in conjunction with the launch of the Coaching Hall of Fame.<ref name=Ind13Dec1998/> The medal and associated awards were launched to raise the profile of coaches, and increase the financial backing to enhance the profession, still seen at the time as a largely amateur vocation in spite of Mussabini's pioneering example.<ref name=Ind13Dec1998/> Speaking at the inaugural presentation the patron of the Foundation the [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Royal]] stated that "Coaching and the work of individual coaches lies at the heart of sport, Yet all too often the role and contribution of the coach remains unrecognised and unacknowledged".<ref name=Ind13Dec1998/>
The Mussabini Medal was awarded to solely British coaches in the first two years, with 2000 being the first time foreign coaches of British athletes were recognised.<ref name=Ind10Dec2000/>

Curling * Wilf Paish – Athletics | * [[John Jacobs (English golfer)|John Jacobs]] – Golf * [[Doug Dailey]] – Cycling * [[Penny Chuter]] – Rowing * Jenny Bott – Gymnastics * Adrian Stan – Gymnastics * Ray Williams – Rugby Union |[https://www.webcitation.org/5kWoXCSzL] |- |2001 | * Alan Edge – Canoeing * Roland Lawler – Canoeing * Ron Roddan – Athletics * Rosemary and Alex Stanton – Athletics | * Tom McNab – Athletics * [[Micky Stewart]] – Cricket * [[Chalkie White (rugby player)|Chalkie White]] – Rugby Union * [[Craig Brown (footballer born 1940)|Craig Brown]] – Football * [[Howard {{short description|Turkish singer and actress}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{infobox person | name = Seda Sayan | image = | caption = | birth_name = Aysel Gürsaçer | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|12|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Istanbul]], Turkey | spouse = Rıdvan Kılıç (1987–1987)
Sinan Engin (1990–1995)
Soner Yapcacık (1998–1999)
Tuncay Kıratlı (2000–2001)
Gökhan Şükür (2004–2005)
Onur Şan (2008–2010) | children = 1 | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|actress|TV presenter}} | years_active = 1978–present | website = http://www.sedasayan.com.tr }} '''Seda Sayan''' (born '''Aysel Gürsaçer''', 30 December 1962{{cite web|url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/printnews.aspx?DocID=226027|accessdate=December 13, 2013|title=Seda yaşını büyütmüş|language=Turkish|date=May 17, 2004|publisher=Hürriyet}}) is a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] pop folk singer, actress, and TV variety-show hostess.[http://kelebek.hurriyet.com.tr/yenianasayfa/6240860.asp?m=1&gid=112&srid=3432&oid=2 Hürriyet - Vergi şampiyonu M. Ali] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002145707/http://kelebek.hurriyet.com.tr/yenianasayfa/6240860.asp?m=1&gid=112&srid=3432&oid=2 |date=October 2, 2011 }} She had her date of birth changed via a court decision in 1978 to 4 January 1959, in order to be eligible for performing at a specific venue. In December 2017, she changed her date of birth back to 1962.{{cite web | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20171227235404/http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/seda-sayan-4-yas-kuculdu-40690216 | url = http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/seda-sayan-4-yas-kuculdu-40690216 | archivedate = 27 December 2017 | title = Seda Sayan 4 yaş küçüldü | publisher = [[Hürriyet]] | date = 26 December 2017}} == Personal life == Sayan was born in a poor family so she had worked from the very young age.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/kelebek/hayat/seda-sayan-kimdir-biyografisi-40078795|title=Seda Sayan kimdir?|publisher=Hürriyet|date=31 March 2016|accessdate=18 September 2018}} She started performing at the age of 16. Her big shot came in 1984 when she played a role in front of [[Kadir İnanır]]. In 1987 she married Rıdvan Kılıç, a soccer player, the marriage did not last long and they divorced a few months later. She met [[Sinan Engin]] in 1989 and they got married. They had their son Oğulcan Engin in 1990, but the couple divorced in 1995. Sayan then developed a relationship with [[Mahsun Kırmızıgül]], a famous singer, for three years. Since 1998 she has had relationships which have not lasted long. She has been known for her controversial lifestyle. She always talks about her very difficult childhood openly and claims to be proud of her origins. ==Discography== ;Albums *1985: ''[[Anılarım]]'' *1987: ''[[Seda Sayan'la Başbaşa]]'' *1989: ''[[Seviyor musun?]]'' *1990: ''[[80'li Yıllar]]'' (featuring [[Nejat Alp]]) *1990: ''[[Ya Benim Olursun]]'' *1991: ''[[Git Demesi Kolay]]'' *1992: ''[[İşte ... Seda Sayan]]'' *1993: ''[[Yeter ki İste]]'' *1994: ''[[Vız Gelir Her Şey]]'' *1996: ''[[Ah Geceler]]'' *1997: ''[[Sensizliğe Yanarım]]'' *1999: ''[[Ben Sana Demedim mi?]]'' *2001: ''[[Var Mısın?]]'' *2004: ''[[Sıkı Sıkı]]'' *2005: ''[[Bebeğim]]'' *2007: ''[[Gecelerce Ağlarsın Unutma]]'' *2009: ''[[Aşkla]]'' *2012: ''[[Seda Sayan 2012]]'' *2014: ''[[Hatıran Yeter]]'' ;Singles *2011: "İftira" *2012: "Yağmur Altında Eriyorum" *2016: "Karagözlüm Ölesim Var" *2017: "Tabi Tabi" == Filmography == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- |1983 | ''Yorgun'' | | |- |- |1984 | ''İmparator'' | | |- |rowspan="2"| 1986 | ''Saide'' | | |- | ''Kanlı Su'' | | |- |rowspan="2"| 1993 | ''Üç İstanbul'' | | |- | ''Geceler'' | Seda | |- | 1997 | ''Sırtımdan Vuruldum'' | Gülnaz | |- | 1999 | ''Evimiz Olacak mı?'' | Filiz | |- |rowspan="2"| 2002 | ''Reyting Hamdi'' | | Supporting role |- | ''Hastayım Doktor'' | Bihter Can | |- | 2004 | ''[[Yabancı Damat]]'' | Herself | Supporting role |- | 2005 | ''Hababam Sınıfı 3,5'' | Deli Bedriye | |- | 2007 | ''Fedai'' | Yıldız Akar | |- | 2008 | ''[[Akasya Durağı]]'' | | Supporting role |- |2012 | ''İkizler Firarda'' | | |} ==TV programs== * ''[[Seda - Osman Show]]'', [[Kanal 6]] * ''[[Yetiş Bacım]]'', [[TGRT]] * ''[[Mahalleler Yarışıyor]]'', [[TGRT]] (2000) * ''[[Sabah Sabah Seda Sayan]]'', [[Kanal D]] (2002) * ''[[Seda Sayan ile Şans Kapısı]]'', [[Kanal D]] * ''[[Sabahların Sultanı Seda Sayan]]'', [[Kanal D]] (2006–2009) * ''[[Susma (TV series)|Susma]]'', [[Kanal D]] (2009) * ''[[Yalnız Değilsiniz]]'', [[Kanal D]] (2009) * ''[[Sabahın Sedası]]'', [[Show TV]] (2010–2011) * ''[[Beyaz'ın Sultanı]]'', [[Beyaz TV]] (2011) * ''[[Seda Sultan]]'', [[TV8 (Turkey)|TV8]] (2012–2013) * ''[[Kaynana Gelin Seda'ya Gelin]]'', [[Kanal D]] (2013–2014) * ''[[Seda Sayan Show]]'', [[Show TV]] (2014) * ''[[Evleneceksen Gel]]'', [[Show TV]] (2015–2017) * ''[[O Ses Türkiye]]'', [[TV8 (Turkey)|TV8]] (2018–present) == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|1856442}} * {{Discogs artist|artist=Seda Sayan|name=Seda Sayan}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sayan, Seda}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:People from Istanbul]] [[Category:Turkish pop-folk singers]] [[Category:Turkish entertainers]] [[Category:Turkish female singers]] [[Category:Turkish pop singers]] [[Category:20th-century Turkish actresses]]

{{Infobox sports club | name = S.F.K. Pierikos | logo = | logo_size = 120px | caption = | full_name = {{lang|el|Σύνδεσμος Φιλάθλων Κατερίνης Πιερικός}}
{{small|(Supporters' Association of Katerini Pierikos)}} | nicknames = {{lang|el|Ο Άρχοντας του Βορρά}}
{{small|(The Lord of the North)}} | founded = 1961 | colours = {{color box|white}} [[White]] | chairman = Georgios Kokavidis | club_titles = | anthem = ''Hymn of Pierikos'' | website = [http://www.pierikos-fc.gr/ pierikos-fc.gr] }} ''' Syndesmos Filathlon Katerinis Pierikos ''' ({{lang-el|Σύνδεσμος Φιλάθλων Κατερίνης Πιερικός}},[http://www.pierikos-fc.gr/ pierikos-fc.gr] {{el}} Supporters' Association of Katerini Pierikos), founded in 1961, is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[Sports club|multi-sport club]] based in the city of [[Katerini]], capital of [[Pieria (regional unit)|Pieria]] [[regional units of Greece|regional unit]], located in [[Central Macedonia|Central Macedonia, Greece]]. The club is also known as '''S.F.K. Pierikos''', or simply '''Pierikos''', and its colors is white.[http://pierikos.info/index.php/95-54-xronia-fanela-logotypo-sfragida 54 years Kit-logo-seal] ==Sport facilities== The football team plays at the [[Katerini Stadium|Municipal Stadium of Katerini]], Pierikos' home since 1961. The club uses also Municipal training facilities in the area of the ''National Stadium District''. The facilities cover over 20,000 square meters. == References == {{reflist}} {{S.F.K. Pierikos}} [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1961]] [[Category:Multi-sport clubs in Greece]] [[Category:Katerini]] {{Greece-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Séwé FC| image = Séwé FC.png| fullname = Séwé FC| nickname = ''Séwéké'' | founded = 1977 | ground = [[Stade Robert Champroux]], [[Ivory Coast]]| capacity = 3,000| president = Paul-Dominique Vacaharasinthu & Eugène-Marie Diomande | manager = Njoya Mesack Mauril league = [[Ligue 1 (Ivory Coast)|Ligue 1]] | season = [[2016-17 Ligue 1 (Ivory Coast)|2016–17]] | position = Ligue 1, 1st | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_SSS_h|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=3e8fde|body1=3e8fde|rightarm1=3e8fde|shorts1=3e8fde|socks1=FFFFFF| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=_SSS_a|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF| pattern_la3=|pattern_b3=_navystripes|pattern_ra3=|pattern_so3=_whitetop| leftarm3=284d94|body3=FFFFFF|rightarm3=284d94|shorts3=284d94|socks3=284d94| }} '''Séwé Football Club''' (formerly '''Séwé Sport de San-Pédro''', referred to as '''Séwé Sport''') is an [[Côte d'Ivoire|Ivorian]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[San Pédro, Ivory Coast|San-Pédro]]. They are a member of the [[Fédération Ivoirienne de Football]] Premiere Division. They play at the [[Stade Municipal (San Pédro)|Stade Municipal]].
The club rebranded as Séwé FC in March 2017.
==Honours== *'''[[Côte d'Ivoire Premier Division]]: 3''' ::2012, 2013, 2014.
*'''[[Côte d'Ivoire Cup]]: 1''' :: 2016.
*'''[[Coupe de la Ligue de Côte d'Ivoire]]: 0'''
*'''[[Coupe Houphouët-Boigny]]: 4''' ::2005, 2012, 2013, 2014.
==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 3 appearances''' ::[[CAF Champions League 2007|2007]] – First Round ::[[2013 CAF Champions League|2013]] – Group stage ::[[2014 CAF Champions League|2014]] – Second Round
*'''[[CAF Confederation Cup]]: 4 appearances''' ::[[CAF Confederation Cup 2006|2006]] – First Round ::[[CAF Confederation Cup 2010|2010]] – First Round ::[[2011 CAF Confederation Cup|2011]] – Preliminary Round ::[[2012 CAF Confederation Cup|2012]] – Preliminary Round ::[[2014 CAF Confederation Cup|2014]] – Runner Up

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Westhills Stadium | image = | image_size= | coordinates = {{coord|48|26|35|N|123|31|10|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | opened = {{Start date|2009}} | owner = [[Langford, British Columbia]] | operator = [[Langford, British Columbia]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|C$]]3 million | tenants = [[Rugby Canada]] (2009–present)
[[BC Bears]] ([[Canadian Rugby Championship|CRC]]) (2009–present)
[[Westshore Rebels]] ([[Canadian Junior Football League|CJFL]]) (2009–present)
[[Victoria Highlanders]] ([[Premier Development League|PDL]]) (2009–2011)
[[Pacific FC]] ([[Canadian Premier League|CPL]]) (from 2019) | seating_capacity = 1,718 }} '''Westhills Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Langford, British Columbia|Langford]], [[British Columbia]]. It is used by [[Rugby Canada]] and the regional team [[BC Bears]] of the [[Canadian Rugby Championship]]; by the [[Westshore Rebels]] football team; and, from 2009 to 2011, by the [[Victoria Highlanders]] soccer team from 2009–2011. In an international context, its most notable usage is as the site of the [[Canada Women's Sevens]], an event in the [[World Rugby Women's Sevens Series]] for national [[rugby sevens]] teams. The stadium has 1,600 permanent seats.Victoria Times Colonist: [http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/story.html?id=fad66d77-1480-4cc1-b385-d9b29df21d6d Langford To Build Its Own Stadium] The main City Centre Park Stadium seats 1,218 under cover, additional temporary seating for 500, 10 club boxes/corporate suites, 4 change rooms, officials' rooms, concession, storage, and public washrooms. The field is built to FIFA 2 Star and [[World Rugby]] specifications, able to accommodate soccer, football, and rugby matches.{{cite web |url= http://www.cityoflangford.ca/assets/Documents~Library/Reports/Annual%20Report%202009.pdf|title= British Columbia: Province Cup 1922–1941| first=Lanford Parks|last=Dept. |date=2009 |work=City of Langford 2009 Annual Report|accessdate=3 April 2013}} There is a second adjacent turf field currently named Goudy Field that has seating for 1,500.Victoria Times Colonist: [http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/sports/story.html?id=9e03c6d8-15ac-4acd-8683-41070aa9cea7&k=14579 Rugby Canada eyes Langford stadium] This second full-sized artificial turf field is also FIFA 2 Star rated and can accommodate the Canadian Rugby Association football codes.{{cite web |url= http://www.cityoflangford.ca/assets/Documents~Library/Reports/Annual%20Report%202010.pdf|title= British Columbia: Province Cup 1922–1941| first=Lanford Parks|last=Dept. |date= 2010 |work=City of Langford 2010 Annual Report|accessdate=3 April 2013}}http://www.cityoflangford.ca/EN/main/lifestyle/amenities/city-centre-park.html Westhills Stadium at City Centre Park is also referred to as City Centre Stadium. On September 29, 2012 Bear Mountain Stadium's name was changed to Westhills Stadium after the land development company.http://www.westhillsbc.com/news/933435037 On July 20, 2018, It was announced that Westhills will host [[Pacific FC]] of the [[Canadian Premier League]] beginning in 2019. The stadium will undergo renovations to increase capacity to 7,500 and provide additional amenities.{{cite web |title=Stadium Profile: Pacific FC |url=http://pacificfc.canpl.ca/stadium-profile |website=pacificfc.canpl.ca |accessdate=July 21, 2018 |language=en-CA}}{{Cite news|url=https://the11.ca/victoria-is-in-for-canpl-league-exploring-several-opportunities-on-lower-mainland/|title=Victoria is in for CanPL: League exploring "several opportunities" on Lower Mainland|date=June 1, 2018|work=The 11|access-date=June 1, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/greater-victoria-to-get-pro-soccer-team-next-year-1.23321490|title=Greater Victoria to get pro soccer team next year|last=Dheensaw|first=Cleve|work=Times Colonist|access-date=June 1, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * http://www.cityoflangford.ca/EN/main/lifestyle/amenities/city-centre-park/city-centre-park-stadium.html * [http://www.jdfsoccer.ca/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=166&Itemid=340 Directions] * http://www.eagleridgecentre.com/facilities/overview-of-facilities {{Pacific FC}} {{Canadian Premier League stadiums}} {{World Rugby Women's Sevens Series}} [[Category:Sports venues in British Columbia]] [[Category:Greater Victoria]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Canada]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues in Victoria, British Columbia]] [[Category:Pacific FC]] [[Category:Canadian Premier League stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in British Columbia]] {{BritishColumbia-struct-stub}} {{Canada-sports-venue-stub}}
